What did early Canadian farmers eat?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. E. B. R. W. H.
Address: M. E. S. K. A. K. A. M., S. A. S. K.
Birthplace: Wantage, Berkshire, England.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1894.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Chambly, Manitoba.
Where had you been living before that? Winnipeg, for 2 years.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3.
How far was it to your nearest store? 14 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every 2 weeks.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? We had very little to buy groceries with, so we just got the bare necessities.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? 2nd grade.
In what quantities did you buy it? 1/2 sack, 4 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50.
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $4.88.
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Whole wheat? Farina?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it?
MRS. E. BORWICK

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 6 lb.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 59¢.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Cream.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.

At that price? $0.24 each.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had our own.

Butter? Enough for our own needs.

What was the price of butter? 12¢ a lb.

Did you pack eggs for market? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We kept a pig to kill.

How did you get fresh meat? We bought it once in a while from Delkirk.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? In the house.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pheasant, quail, rabbit, raccoon.

For how long? During the winter months.

What part did fish play in the family diet? We got fish from the Indians about every two weeks.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Jackfish, Catfish, Goldeyes, Perch.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose. At what price? 4c.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground. Price? 40¢.

Apples

18. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two lonely prairie roads? Give details.

I am afraid I did not live as far back as some of these questions seem to indicate.

I am nearly 79 & have lived in Canada since 1892 have been many changes, probably twice we hardly knew where the next meal would come from. Your husband only had a small farm.

He would take a few cows of wood & honey bee.

But I am still here & I am 75 & we only had two cows after the road came from the east.

---

19. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada after your marriage?

Give the menu. List those present and five things appreciated about the time.
a pint of milk a day & good enough butter & we'll be treated.
a pint of milk a day & just enough butter to use on our bread.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In early days you could always get sugar & we used it for puddings. We could get it 3 lbs for 25¢ & some we rendered & used it to make bannock, my husband had always been used to bannock when he was a boy! They used nothing but, he was born in Manitoba & his Mother & Father before him.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Have always lived on home grown foods as much as possible.
